1→// ABOUTME: Multi-section grouped list configuration with headers and footers.
     2→// ABOUTME: Manages UICollectionView layout, data source, and delegate internally.
     3→import ListKit
     4→import UIKit
     5→
     6→/// A multi-section list with headers and footers, backed by a `UICollectionView`.
     7→///
     8→/// `GroupedList` manages an inset-grouped layout with supplementary header/footer views
     9→/// automatically. Provide ``SectionModel`` values to populate sections.
    10→///
    11→/// ## Layout Configuration
    12→///
    13→/// Layout properties (`appearance`, `showsSeparators`, `headerMode`, `footerMode`,
    14→/// `separatorColor`, `backgroundColor`, `headerTopPadding`) are set during initialization
    15→/// and cannot be changed afterward. This is a UIKit limitation —
    16→/// `UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration` is snapshot-immutable once the layout is created.
    17→/// Dynamic properties like ``allowsMultipleSelection`` and ``isEditing`` can be changed
    18→/// at any time.
    19→///
    20→/// ```swift
    21→/// let list = GroupedList<String, ContactItem>()
    22→/// await list.setSections([
    23→///     SectionModel(id: "friends", items: friends, header: "Friends"),
    24→/// ])
    25→/// ```
    26→@MainActor
    27→public final class GroupedList<SectionID: Hashable & Sendable, Item: CellViewModel>: NSObject, UICollectionViewDelegate,
    28→  ListConfigurable
    29→{
    30→
    31→  // MARK: Lifecycle
    32→
    33→  deinit {
    34→    applyTask?.cancel()
    35→    refreshManager.cancel()
    36→  }
    37→
    38→  /// Creates a grouped list with the specified list appearance.
    39→  ///
    40→  /// - Parameters:
    41→  ///   - appearance: The visual style of the list (e.g., `.insetGrouped`, `.plain`, `.sidebar`).
    42→  ///   - showsSeparators: Whether separators are shown between rows.
    43→  ///   - headerMode: How section headers are displayed. Defaults to `.supplementary`.
    44→  ///   - footerMode: How section footers are displayed. Defaults to `.supplementary`.
    45→  ///   - separatorColor: A global tint color applied to all item separators. Per-item
    46→  ///     customization via ``separatorHandler`` takes precedence.
    47→  ///   - backgroundColor: An optional background color for the list. When `nil`, the system default is used.
    48→  ///   - headerTopPadding: Extra padding above each section header. When `nil`, the system default is used.
    49→  public init(
    50→    appearance: UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration.Appearance = .insetGrouped,
    51→    showsSeparators: Bool = true,
    52→    headerMode: UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration.HeaderMode = .supplementary,
    53→    footerMode: UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration.FooterMode = .supplementary,
    54→    separatorColor: UIColor? = nil,
    55→    backgroundColor: UIColor? = nil,
    56→    headerTopPadding: CGFloat? = nil
    57→  ) {
    58→    let bridge = ListConfigurationBridge<SectionID, Item>()
    59→    self.bridge = bridge
    60→    bridge.setDefaultSeparatorColor(separatorColor)
    61→
    62→    var config = UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration(appearance: appearance)
    63→    config.headerMode = headerMode
    64→    config.footerMode = footerMode
    65→    config.showsSeparators = showsSeparators
    66→    if let backgroundColor {
    67→      config.backgroundColor = backgroundColor
    68→    }
    69→    if let headerTopPadding {
    70→      config.headerTopPadding = headerTopPadding
    71→    }
    72→    bridge.configure(&config)
    73→    let layout = UICollectionViewCompositionalLayout.list(using: config)
    74→
    75→    collectionView = UICollectionView(frame: .zero, collectionViewLayout: layout)
    76→    dataSource = ListDataSource(collectionView: collectionView)
    77→    super.init()
    78→    collectionView.delegate = self
    79→    refreshManager.attach(to: collectionView)
    80→    // Register supplementary views only when at least one mode is .supplementary.
    81→    // Both header and footer registrations are created together; the layout only
    82→    // requests the kinds matching its configuration, so unused registrations are inert.
    83→    if headerMode == .supplementary || footerMode == .supplementary {
    84→      setupSupplementaryViews()
    85→    }
    86→
    87→    bridge.setDataSource(dataSource)
    88→    // trailingSwipeActionsProvider takes precedence; onDelete is the fallback.
    89→    bridge.setTrailingProvider { [weak self] item in
    90→      guard let self else { return nil }
    91→      if let config = trailingSwipeActionsProvider?(item) {
    92→        return config
    93→      }
    94→      guard let onDelete else { return nil }
    95→      let action = UIContextualAction(style: .destructive, title: String(localized: "Delete")) { _, _, completion in
    96→        onDelete(item)
    97→        completion(true)
    98→      }
    99→      return UISwipeActionsConfiguration(actions: [action])
   100→    }
   101→    bridge.setLeadingProvider { [weak self] item in self?.leadingSwipeActionsProvider?(item) }
   102→  }
   103→
   104→  // MARK: Public
   105→
   106→  /// A convenience alias for the snapshot type used by this list.
   107→  public typealias Snapshot = DiffableDataSourceSnapshot<SectionID, Item>
   108→
   109→  /// The underlying collection view. Add this to your view hierarchy.
   110→  public let collectionView: UICollectionView
   111→  /// Called when the user taps an item.
   112→  public var onSelect: (@MainActor (Item) -> Void)?
   113→  /// Called when the user deselects an item (relevant when `allowsMultipleSelection` is enabled).
   114→  public var onDeselect: (@MainActor (Item) -> Void)?
   115→
   116→  /// Called when the user swipe-deletes an item. When set and ``trailingSwipeActionsProvider``
   117→  /// is `nil`, a trailing destructive "Delete" swipe action is provided automatically.
   118→  ///
   119→  /// - Important: The caller is responsible for removing the item from the data source
   120→  ///   after this callback fires. The list does not automatically mutate its snapshot.
   121→  ///
   122→  /// - Note: The swipe action always completes as "performed" regardless of whether the
   123→  ///   underlying operation succeeds. Ensure your handler updates the data source to
   124→  ///   reflect the actual result.
   125→  public var onDelete: (@MainActor (Item) -> Void)?
   126→
   127→  /// Closure that returns trailing swipe actions for a given item.
   128→  public var trailingSwipeActionsProvider: (@MainActor (Item) -> UISwipeActionsConfiguration?)?
   129→  /// Closure that returns leading swipe actions for a given item.
   130→  public var leadingSwipeActionsProvider: (@MainActor (Item) -> UISwipeActionsConfiguration?)?
   131→  /// Closure that returns a context menu configuration for a given item.
   132→  public var contextMenuProvider: (@MainActor (Item) -> UIContextMenuConfiguration?)?
   133→
   134→  /// Optional closure called before an item is selected. Return `false` to prevent selection.
   135→  ///
   136→  /// Use this to implement conditional selection (e.g. disabling taps on certain items):
   137→  /// ```swift
   138→  /// list.shouldSelect = { item in !item.isDisabled }
   139→  /// ```
   140→  public var shouldSelect: (@MainActor (Item) -> Bool)?
   141→
   142→  /// Closure that returns a custom content configuration for a section header.
   143→  ///
   144→  /// When set, this takes precedence over the text-based header from ``SectionModel``.
   145→  /// Return `nil` to fall back to the text header for a specific section.
   146→  ///
   147→  /// ```swift
   148→  /// list.headerContentProvider = { sectionID in
   149→  ///     var config = UIListContentConfiguration.prominentInsetGroupedHeader()
   150→  ///     config.text = sectionID
   151→  ///     config.image = UIImage(systemName: "star")
   152→  ///     return config
   153→  /// }
   154→  /// ```
   155→  public var headerContentProvider: (@MainActor (SectionID) -> UIContentConfiguration?)?
   156→
   157→  /// Closure that returns a custom content configuration for a section footer.
   158→  ///
   159→  /// When set, this takes precedence over the text-based footer from ``SectionModel``.
   160→  /// Return `nil` to fall back to the text footer for a specific section.
   161→  public var footerContentProvider: (@MainActor (SectionID) -> UIContentConfiguration?)?
   162→
   163→  /// An optional delegate that receives `UIScrollViewDelegate` callbacks from the underlying
   164→  /// collection view's scroll view.
   165→  ///
   166→  /// Use this to track scroll position, detect user-initiated drags, or respond to deceleration
   167→  /// events without replacing the collection view's delegate (which the list manages internally).
   168→  public weak var scrollViewDelegate: UIScrollViewDelegate?
   169→
   170→  /// Per-item separator customization handler.
   171→  ///
   172→  /// Called for each item before display. Return a modified configuration to customize
   173→  /// separator appearance (color, insets, visibility) on a per-item basis.
   174→  ///
   175→  /// ```swift
   176→  /// list.separatorHandler = { item, defaultConfig in
   177→  ///     var config = defaultConfig
   178→  ///     config.color = .systemRed
   179→  ///     config.bottomSeparatorInsets.leading = 16
   180→  ///     return config
   181→  /// }
   182→  /// ```
   183→  public var separatorHandler: (@MainActor (Item, UIListSeparatorConfiguration) -> UIListSeparatorConfiguration)? {
   184→    didSet { bridge.setSeparatorProvider(separatorHandler) }
   185→  }
   186→
   187→  /// An async closure invoked on pull-to-refresh. The refresh control is dismissed
   188→  /// automatically when the closure returns.
   189→  ///
   190→  /// ```swift
   191→  /// list.onRefresh = {
   192→  ///     let sections = try? await api.fetchSections()
   193→  ///     await list.setSections(sections ?? [])
   194→  /// }
   195→  /// ```
   196→  public var onRefresh: (@MainActor () async -> Void)? {
   197→    didSet { refreshManager.onRefresh = onRefresh }
   198→  }
   199→
   200→  /// Called when the user reorders an item via drag-and-drop.
   201→  /// The list updates its internal snapshot automatically; use this to persist the new order.
   202→  /// Setting this enables the reorder interaction on the collection view.
   203→  public var onMove: (@MainActor (_ source: IndexPath, _ destination: IndexPath) -> Void)? {
   204→    didSet { configureReorderIfNeeded() }
   205→  }
   206→
   207→  /// Optional closure that determines whether a specific item can be reordered.
   208→  ///
   209→  /// When set, this is called for each item when drag begins. Return `false` to prevent
   210→  /// an item from being dragged. When `nil`, all items are moveable (if `onMove` is set).
   211→  public var canMoveItemProvider: (@MainActor (Item) -> Bool)? {
   212→    didSet { configureReorderIfNeeded() }
   213→  }
   214→
   215→  /// Replaces all sections, computing and animating the diff.
   216→  ///
   217→  /// Cancels any previously queued apply so only the most recent snapshot is applied,
   218→  /// and supports cooperative cancellation from the calling task.
   219→  public func setSections(_ sections: [SectionModel<SectionID, Item>], animatingDifferences: Bool = true) async {
   220→    applyTask?.cancel()
   221→    let previousTask = applyTask
   222→    let task = Task { [weak self] in
   223→      _ = await previousTask?.value
   224→      guard !Task.isCancelled, let self else { return }
   225→      var newHeaders = [SectionID: String]()
   226→      var newFooters = [SectionID: String]()
   227→      for section in sections {
   228→        if let header = section.header {
   229→          newHeaders[section.id] = header
   230→        }
   231→        if let footer = section.footer {
   232→          newFooters[section.id] = footer
   233→        }
   234→      }
   235→      // Merge new values so both old and new sections have valid headers during animation
   236→      sectionHeaders.merge(newHeaders) { _, new in new }
   237→      sectionFooters.merge(newFooters) { _, new in new }
   238→      await dataSource.apply(sections, animatingDifferences: animatingDifferences)
   239→      // Trim to only current sections after apply completes
   240→      sectionHeaders = newHeaders
   241→      sectionFooters = newFooters
   242→      collectionView.backgroundView?.isHidden = !sections.allSatisfy(\.items.isEmpty)
   243→    }
   244→    applyTask = task
   245→    await withTaskCancellationHandler {
   246→      await task.value
   247→    } onCancel: {
   248→      task.cancel()
   249→    }
   250→  }
   251→
   252→  /// Replaces all sections using the ``SnapshotBuilder`` result builder DSL.
   253→  ///
   254→  /// ``SnapshotSection`` supports optional `header` and `footer` text that maps directly
   255→  /// to ``SectionModel`` headers/footers. For fully custom supplementary content, set
   256→  /// ``headerContentProvider`` / ``footerContentProvider`` instead.
   257→  ///
   258→  /// ```swift
   259→  /// await list.setSections {
   260→  ///     SnapshotSection("favorites", header: "Favorites") {
   261→  ///         favoriteItem1
   262→  ///         favoriteItem2
   263→  ///     }
   264→  ///     SnapshotSection("recent", header: "Recent") {
   265→  ///         recentItem1
   266→  ///     }
   267→  /// }
   268→  /// ```
   269→  public func setSections(
   270→    animatingDifferences: Bool = true,
   271→    @SnapshotBuilder<SectionID, Item> content: () -> [SnapshotSection<SectionID, Item>]
   272→  ) async {
   273→    let sections = content().map { section in
   274→      SectionModel(id: section.id, items: section.items, header: section.header, footer: section.footer)
   275→    }
   276→    await setSections(sections, animatingDifferences: animatingDifferences)
   277→  }
   278→
   279→  /// Returns a copy of the current snapshot.
   280→  public func snapshot() -> DiffableDataSourceSnapshot<SectionID, Item> {
   281→    dataSource.snapshot()
   282→  }
   283→
   284→  /// Returns the item at the given index path, or `nil` if out of bounds.
   285→  public func itemIdentifier(for indexPath: IndexPath) -> Item? {
   286→    bridge.itemIdentifier(for: indexPath)
   287→  }
   288→
   289→  /// Returns the index path for the specified item, or `nil` if not found.
   290→  public func indexPath(for item: Item) -> IndexPath? {
   291→    bridge.indexPath(for: item)
   292→  }
   293→
   294→  /// Returns the section identifier at the given section index, or `nil` if out of bounds.
   295→  public func sectionIdentifier(for index: Int) -> SectionID? {
   296→    bridge.sectionIdentifier(for: index)
   297→  }
   298→
   299→  /// Returns the index of the specified section identifier, or `nil` if not found.
   300→  public func index(for sectionIdentifier: SectionID) -> Int? {
   301→    bridge.index(for: sectionIdentifier)
   302→  }
   303→
   304→  /// Returns the items in the specified section, or `nil` if the section is not found.
   305→  public func items(in section: SectionID) -> [Item]? {
   306→    let snap = dataSource.snapshot()
   307→    guard snap.sectionIdentifiers.contains(section) else { return nil }
   308→    return snap.itemIdentifiers(inSection: section)
   309→  }

   378→  // MARK: Private
   379→
   380→  private let dataSource: ListDataSource<SectionID, Item>
   381→  private let bridge: ListConfigurationBridge<SectionID, Item>
   382→  private let refreshManager = RefreshControlManager()
   383→  private var sectionHeaders = [SectionID: String]()
   384→  private var sectionFooters = [SectionID: String]()
   385→  private var applyTask: Task<Void, Never>?
   386→
   387→  private func configureReorderIfNeeded() {
   388→    if onMove != nil {
   389→      collectionView.dragInteractionEnabled = true
   390→      if let canMoveItemProvider {
   391→        dataSource.canMoveItemHandler = { [weak self] indexPath in
   392→          guard let item = self?.bridge.itemIdentifier(for: indexPath) else { return false }
   393→          return canMoveItemProvider(item)
   394→        }
   395→      } else {
   396→        dataSource.canMoveItemHandler = { _ in true }
   397→      }
   398→      dataSource.didMoveItemHandler = { [weak self] source, dest in
   399→        self?.onMove?(source, dest)
   400→      }
   401→    } else {
   402→      collectionView.dragInteractionEnabled = false
   403→      dataSource.canMoveItemHandler = nil
   404→      dataSource.didMoveItemHandler = nil
   405→    }
   406→  }
   407→
   408→  private func setupSupplementaryViews() {
   409→    let headerRegistration = UICollectionView.SupplementaryRegistration<UICollectionViewListCell>(
   410→      elementKind: UICollectionView.elementKindSectionHeader
   411→    ) { [weak self] supplementaryView, _, indexPath in
   412→      guard let self else { return }
   413→      guard let sectionID = dataSource.sectionIdentifier(for: indexPath.section) else {
   414→        assertionFailure("Section index \(indexPath.section) out of bounds")
   415→        return
   416→      }
   417→      if let contentConfig = headerContentProvider?(sectionID) {
   418→        supplementaryView.contentConfiguration = contentConfig
   419→      } else {
   420→        var content = UIListContentConfiguration.groupedHeader()
   421→        content.text = sectionHeaders[sectionID]
   422→        supplementaryView.contentConfiguration = content
   423→      }
   424→    }
   425→
   426→    let footerRegistration = UICollectionView.SupplementaryRegistration<UICollectionViewListCell>(
   427→      elementKind: UICollectionView.elementKindSectionFooter
   428→    ) { [weak self] supplementaryView, _, indexPath in
   429→      guard let self else { return }
   430→      guard let sectionID = dataSource.sectionIdentifier(for: indexPath.section) else {
   431→        assertionFailure("Section index \(indexPath.section) out of bounds")
   432→        return
   433→      }
   434→      if let contentConfig = footerContentProvider?(sectionID) {
   435→        supplementaryView.contentConfiguration = contentConfig
   436→      } else {
   437→        var content = UIListContentConfiguration.groupedFooter()
   438→        content.text = sectionFooters[sectionID]
   439→        supplementaryView.contentConfiguration = content
   440→      }
   441→    }
   442→
   443→    dataSource.supplementaryViewProvider = { collectionView, kind, indexPath in
   444→      switch kind {
   445→      case UICollectionView.elementKindSectionHeader:
   446→        return collectionView.dequeueConfiguredReusableSupplementary(using: headerRegistration, for: indexPath)
   447→      case UICollectionView.elementKindSectionFooter:
   448→        return collectionView.dequeueConfiguredReusableSupplementary(using: footerRegistration, for: indexPath)
   449→      default:
   450→        assertionFailure("Unexpected supplementary view kind: \(kind)")
   451→        return nil
   452→      }
   453→    }
   454→  }
   455→}

1→// ABOUTME: Hierarchical outline list with expand/collapse via section snapshots.
     2→// ABOUTME: Defines OutlineItem (tree node) and OutlineList (UICollectionView config).
     3→import ListKit
     4→import UIKit
     5→
     6→// MARK: - OutlineItem
     7→
     8→/// A node in a tree structure used by ``OutlineList`` to represent hierarchical data.
     9→///
    10→/// Each `OutlineItem` wraps a value and optionally has children. The `isExpanded` flag
    11→/// controls whether children are visible when the outline is rendered.
    12→public struct OutlineItem<Item: Hashable & Sendable>: Sendable, Equatable, Identifiable {
    13→
    14→  // MARK: Lifecycle
    15→
    16→  /// Creates an outline item with optional children and expansion state.
    17→  public init(item: Item, children: [OutlineItem<Item>] = [], isExpanded: Bool = false) {
    18→    self.item = item
    19→    self.children = children
    20→    self.isExpanded = isExpanded
    21→  }
    22→
    23→  // MARK: Public
    24→
    25→  /// The data value for this node.
    26→  public let item: Item
    27→  /// The child nodes. Empty for leaf items.
    28→  public let children: [OutlineItem<Item>]
    29→  /// Whether this node's children should be visible.
    30→  public let isExpanded: Bool
    31→
    32→  /// The identity of this outline item, derived from its ``item`` value.
    33→  public var id: Item {
    34→    item
    35→  }
    36→
    37→  /// Recursively transforms every `item` in this tree using the given closure.
    38→  public func mapItems<T: Hashable & Sendable>(_ transform: (Item) -> T) -> OutlineItem<T> {
    39→    OutlineItem<T>(
    40→      item: transform(item),
    41→      children: children.map { $0.mapItems(transform) },
    42→      isExpanded: isExpanded
    43→    )
    44→  }
    45→}

    47→// MARK: - OutlineList
    48→
    49→/// A hierarchical outline list backed by a `UICollectionView` with section snapshots.
    50→///
    51→/// `OutlineList` uses ``DiffableDataSourceSectionSnapshot`` under the hood to model
    52→/// parent–child relationships. Items can be expanded or collapsed.
    53→///
    54→/// - Note: Unlike ``SimpleList`` and ``GroupedList``, `OutlineList` does not support
    55→///   drag-and-drop reordering (`onMove`) due to the complexity of hierarchical move
    56→///   constraints. Use a flat list if reordering is required.
    57→///
    58→/// ## Layout Configuration
    59→///
    60→/// Layout properties (`appearance`, `showsSeparators`, `separatorColor`, `backgroundColor`,
    61→/// `headerTopPadding`) are set during initialization and cannot be changed afterward.
    62→/// This is a UIKit limitation — `UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration` is snapshot-immutable
    63→/// once the layout is created. Dynamic properties like ``allowsMultipleSelection`` and
    64→/// ``isEditing`` can be changed at any time.
    65→///
    66→/// ```swift
    67→/// let list = OutlineList<FileItem>()
    68→/// await list.setItems([
    69→///     OutlineItem(item: folder, children: [
    70→///         OutlineItem(item: file)
    71→///     ], isExpanded: true)
    72→/// ])
    73→/// ```
    74→@MainActor
    75→public final class OutlineList<Item: CellViewModel>: NSObject, UICollectionViewDelegate, ListConfigurable {
    76→
    77→  // MARK: Lifecycle
    78→
    79→  deinit {
    80→    applyTask?.cancel()
    81→    refreshManager.cancel()
    82→  }
    83→
    84→  /// Creates an outline list with the specified list appearance.
    85→  ///
    86→  /// - Parameters:
    87→  ///   - appearance: The visual style of the list (e.g., `.sidebar`, `.plain`, `.insetGrouped`).
    88→  ///   - showsSeparators: Whether separators are shown between rows.
    89→  ///   - separatorColor: A global tint color applied to all item separators. Per-item
    90→  ///     customization via ``separatorHandler`` takes precedence.
    91→  ///   - backgroundColor: An optional background color for the list. When `nil`, the system default is used.
    92→  ///   - headerTopPadding: Extra padding above each section header. When `nil`, the system default is used.
    93→  public init(
    94→    appearance: UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration.Appearance = .sidebar,
    95→    showsSeparators: Bool = true,
    96→    separatorColor: UIColor? = nil,
    97→    backgroundColor: UIColor? = nil,
    98→    headerTopPadding: CGFloat? = nil
    99→  ) {
   100→    let bridge = ListConfigurationBridge<Int, Item>()
   101→    self.bridge = bridge
   102→    bridge.setDefaultSeparatorColor(separatorColor)
   103→
   104→    var config = UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration(appearance: appearance)
   105→    config.showsSeparators = showsSeparators
   106→    if let backgroundColor {
   107→      config.backgroundColor = backgroundColor
   108→    }
   109→    if let headerTopPadding {
   110→      config.headerTopPadding = headerTopPadding
   111→    }
   112→    bridge.configure(&config)
   113→    let layout = UICollectionViewCompositionalLayout.list(using: config)
   114→
   115→    collectionView = UICollectionView(frame: .zero, collectionViewLayout: layout)
   116→    dataSource = ListDataSource(collectionView: collectionView)
   117→    super.init()
   118→    collectionView.delegate = self
   119→    refreshManager.attach(to: collectionView)
   120→
   121→    bridge.setDataSource(dataSource)
   122→    // trailingSwipeActionsProvider takes precedence; onDelete is the fallback.
   123→    bridge.setTrailingProvider { [weak self] item in
   124→      guard let self else { return nil }
   125→      if let config = trailingSwipeActionsProvider?(item) {
   126→        return config
   127→      }
   128→      guard let onDelete else { return nil }
   129→      let action = UIContextualAction(style: .destructive, title: String(localized: "Delete")) { _, _, completion in
   130→        onDelete(item)
   131→        completion(true)
   132→      }
   133→      return UISwipeActionsConfiguration(actions: [action])
   134→    }
   135→    bridge.setLeadingProvider { [weak self] item in self?.leadingSwipeActionsProvider?(item) }
   136→  }
   137→
   138→  // MARK: Public
   139→
   140→  /// A convenience alias for the snapshot type used by this list.
   141→  public typealias Snapshot = DiffableDataSourceSnapshot<Int, Item>
   142→
   143→  /// The underlying collection view. Add this to your view hierarchy.
   144→  public let collectionView: UICollectionView
   145→  /// Called when the user taps an item.
   146→  public var onSelect: (@MainActor (Item) -> Void)?
   147→  /// Called when the user deselects an item (relevant when `allowsMultipleSelection` is enabled).
   148→  public var onDeselect: (@MainActor (Item) -> Void)?
   149→
   150→  /// Called when the user swipe-deletes an item. When set and ``trailingSwipeActionsProvider``
   151→  /// is `nil`, a trailing destructive "Delete" swipe action is provided automatically.
   152→  ///
   153→  /// - Important: The caller is responsible for removing the item from the data source
   154→  ///   after this callback fires. The list does not automatically mutate its snapshot.
   155→  ///
   156→  /// - Note: The swipe action always completes as "performed" regardless of whether the
   157→  ///   underlying operation succeeds. Ensure your handler updates the data source to
   158→  ///   reflect the actual result.
   159→  public var onDelete: (@MainActor (Item) -> Void)?
   160→
   161→  /// Closure that returns trailing swipe actions for a given item.
   162→  public var trailingSwipeActionsProvider: (@MainActor (Item) -> UISwipeActionsConfiguration?)?
   163→  /// Closure that returns leading swipe actions for a given item.
   164→  public var leadingSwipeActionsProvider: (@MainActor (Item) -> UISwipeActionsConfiguration?)?
   165→  /// Closure that returns a context menu configuration for a given item.
   166→  public var contextMenuProvider: (@MainActor (Item) -> UIContextMenuConfiguration?)?
   167→
   168→  /// Optional closure called before an item is selected. Return `false` to prevent selection.
   169→  ///
   170→  /// Use this to implement conditional selection (e.g. disabling taps on certain items):
   171→  /// ```swift
   172→  /// list.shouldSelect = { item in !item.isDisabled }
   173→  /// ```
   174→  public var shouldSelect: (@MainActor (Item) -> Bool)?
   175→
   176→  /// An optional delegate that receives `UIScrollViewDelegate` callbacks from the underlying
   177→  /// collection view's scroll view.
   178→  ///
   179→  /// Use this to track scroll position, detect user-initiated drags, or respond to deceleration
   180→  /// events without replacing the collection view's delegate (which the list manages internally).
   181→  public weak var scrollViewDelegate: UIScrollViewDelegate?
   182→
   183→  /// An async closure invoked on pull-to-refresh. The refresh control is dismissed
   184→  /// automatically when the closure returns.
   185→  ///
   186→  /// ```swift
   187→  /// list.onRefresh = {
   188→  ///     let items = try? await api.fetchTree()
   189→  ///     await list.setItems(items ?? [])
   190→  /// }
   191→  /// ```
   192→  public var onRefresh: (@MainActor () async -> Void)? {
   193→    didSet { refreshManager.onRefresh = onRefresh }
   194→  }
   195→
   196→  /// Per-item separator customization handler.
   197→  ///
   198→  /// Called for each item before display. Return a modified configuration to customize
   199→  /// separator appearance (color, insets, visibility) on a per-item basis.
   200→  ///
   201→  /// ```swift
   202→  /// list.separatorHandler = { item, defaultConfig in
   203→  ///     var config = defaultConfig
   204→  ///     config.color = .systemRed
   205→  ///     config.bottomSeparatorInsets.leading = 16
   206→  ///     return config
   207→  /// }
   208→  /// ```
   209→  public var separatorHandler: (@MainActor (Item, UIListSeparatorConfiguration) -> UIListSeparatorConfiguration)? {
   210→    didSet { bridge.setSeparatorProvider(separatorHandler) }
   211→  }
   212→
   213→  /// All items in the outline, including items hidden under collapsed parents.
   214→  public var allItems: [Item] {
   215→    currentSectionSnapshot?.items ?? []
   216→  }
   217→
   218→  /// The currently visible items (excludes items under collapsed parents).
   219→  public var visibleItems: [Item] {
   220→    currentSectionSnapshot?.visibleItems ?? []
   221→  }
   222→
   223→  /// The root-level items in the outline.
   224→  public var rootItems: [Item] {
   225→    currentSectionSnapshot?.rootItems ?? []
   226→  }
   227→
   228→  /// Returns the parent of the specified item, or `nil` if it is a root item.
   229→  public func parent(of item: Item) -> Item? {
   230→    currentSectionSnapshot?.parent(of: item)
   231→  }
   232→
   233→  /// Returns the nesting level of the specified item (0 for root items).
   234→  public func level(of item: Item) -> Int {
   235→    currentSectionSnapshot?.level(of: item) ?? 0
   236→  }
   237→
   238→  /// Replaces the outline's tree, computing and animating the diff.
   239→  ///
   240→  /// Uses `apply(_:to:animatingDifferences:)` with a section snapshot so UIKit handles
   241→  /// hierarchy natively — expand/collapse animations and optimized subtree diffing come
   242→  /// for free instead of forcing a full flat diff on every update.
   243→  ///
   244→  /// Cancels any previously queued apply so only the most recent snapshot is applied,
   245→  /// and supports cooperative cancellation from the calling task.
   246→  public func setItems(_ items: [OutlineItem<Item>], animatingDifferences: Bool = true) async {
   247→    applyTask?.cancel()
   248→    let previousTask = applyTask
   249→    let task = Task { [weak self] in
   250→      _ = await previousTask?.value
   251→      guard !Task.isCancelled, let self else { return }
   252→
   253→      // Ensure the section exists before applying the section snapshot.
   254→      var mainSnapshot = dataSource.snapshot()
   255→      if mainSnapshot.numberOfSections == 0 {
   256→        mainSnapshot.appendSections([0])
   257→        await dataSource.apply(mainSnapshot, animatingDifferences: false)
   258→        guard !Task.isCancelled else { return }
   259→      }
   260→
   261→      var sectionSnapshot = DiffableDataSourceSectionSnapshot<Item>()
   262→      appendItems(items, to: nil, in: &sectionSnapshot)
   263→      currentSectionSnapshot = sectionSnapshot
   264→      await dataSource.apply(sectionSnapshot, to: 0, animatingDifferences: animatingDifferences)
   265→      collectionView.backgroundView?.isHidden = !items.isEmpty
   266→    }
   267→    applyTask = task
   268→    await withTaskCancellationHandler {
   269→      await task.value
   270→    } onCancel: {
   271→      task.cancel()
   272→    }
   273→  }
   274→
   275→  /// Programmatically expands the specified item, making its children visible.
   276→  ///
   277→  /// This method participates in the same task serialization chain as ``setItems(_:animatingDifferences:)``
   278→  /// to prevent interleaved applies.
   279→  ///
   280→  /// - Parameters:
   281→  ///   - item: The item to expand. Must be present in the current outline and have children.
   282→  ///   - animated: Whether to animate the expansion. Defaults to `true`.
   283→  public func expand(_ item: Item, animated: Bool = true) async {
   284→    applyTask?.cancel()
   285→    let previousTask = applyTask
   286→    let task = Task { [weak self] in
   287→      _ = await previousTask?.value
   288→      guard !Task.isCancelled, let self else { return }
   289→      guard var sectionSnapshot = currentSectionSnapshot, sectionSnapshot.contains(item) else { return }
   290→      sectionSnapshot.expand([item])
   291→      currentSectionSnapshot = sectionSnapshot
   292→      await dataSource.apply(sectionSnapshot, to: 0, animatingDifferences: animated)
   293→    }
   294→    applyTask = task
   295→    await withTaskCancellationHandler { await task.value } onCancel: { task.cancel() }
   296→  }
   297→
   298→  /// Programmatically collapses the specified item, hiding its children.
   299→  ///
   300→  /// This method participates in the same task serialization chain as ``setItems(_:animatingDifferences:)``
   301→  /// to prevent interleaved applies.
   302→  ///
   303→  /// - Parameters:
   304→  ///   - item: The item to collapse. Must be present in the current outline and have children.
   305→  ///   - animated: Whether to animate the collapse. Defaults to `true`.
   306→  public func collapse(_ item: Item, animated: Bool = true) async {
   307→    applyTask?.cancel()
   308→    let previousTask = applyTask
   309→    let task = Task { [weak self] in
   310→      _ = await previousTask?.value
   311→      guard !Task.isCancelled, let self else { return }
   312→      guard var sectionSnapshot = currentSectionSnapshot, sectionSnapshot.contains(item) else { return }
   313→      sectionSnapshot.collapse([item])
   314→      currentSectionSnapshot = sectionSnapshot
   315→      await dataSource.apply(sectionSnapshot, to: 0, animatingDifferences: animated)
   316→    }
   317→    applyTask = task
   318→    await withTaskCancellationHandler { await task.value } onCancel: { task.cancel() }
   319→  }
   320→
   321→  /// Returns whether the specified item is currently expanded.
   322→  ///
   323→  /// - Parameter item: The item to check.
   324→  /// - Returns: `true` if the item is expanded, `false` if collapsed or not found.
   325→  public func isExpanded(_ item: Item) -> Bool {
   326→    currentSectionSnapshot?.isExpanded(item) ?? false
   327→  }

   329→  /// Replaces the outline's tree using the ``OutlineItemBuilder`` result builder DSL.
   330→  ///
   331→  /// ```swift
   332→  /// await list.setItems {
   333→  ///     OutlineItem(item: folder, isExpanded: true) {

   341→    animatingDifferences: Bool = true,

# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.1.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added

- Added `ListConfigurable` protocol that provides shared convenience APIs (`backgroundView`, `allowsMultipleSelection`, `isEditing`, `numberOfItems`, `selectedItems`, `selectItem`, `deselectItem`, `deselectAll`, `scrollToTop`, `scrollToBottom`, `scrollToItem`, and more) via protocol extension — adding a new convenience method to this protocol automatically provides it to `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList`

### Changed

- Extracted shared `computeItemsToReconfigure` function from `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource`, deduplicating the autoReconfigure algorithm

### Fixed

- Fixed `MixedListDataSource.apply(_:to:animatingDifferences:)` bypassing `autoReconfigure`, so `ContentEquatable` items now correctly trigger reconfiguration when applied via section snapshots
- Fixed `OutlineList.setItems` not reconfiguring cells when `CellViewModel` conforms to `ContentEquatable` and content changes but identity stays the same ([#65](https://github.com/Iron-Ham/Lists/issues/65))

## [0.6.5] - 2026-02-20

### Fixed

- Fixed Mac Catalyst refresh control guard to use process-level `UIDevice.current.userInterfaceIdiom` instead of `UIView.behavioralStyle`, which does not resolve correctly before the view is in a window hierarchy

## [0.6.4] - 2026-02-20

# Lists Module — Agent Instructions

> `CLAUDE.md` is a symlink to this file. Always edit `AGENTS.md`.

## Module Purpose

Lists is the high-level, developer-facing API built on top of ListKit. It provides:

- **`CellViewModel` protocol** — the core abstraction tying cell content to diffable identity
- **Data sources** — `ListDataSource` (single type) and `MixedListDataSource` (heterogeneous)
- **Result builder DSL** — `@SnapshotBuilder`, `@ItemsBuilder`, `@MixedSnapshotBuilder`
- **Pre-built configurations** — `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, `OutlineList`
- **SwiftUI wrappers** — `SimpleListView`, `GroupedListView`, `OutlineListView`
- **Accessories** — `ListAccessory` enum mapping to `UICellAccessory`

## Directory Structure

```
Lists/
├── Protocols/
│   ├── CellViewModel.swift          — Core protocol: Hashable + Sendable + cell configuration
│   ├── ListConfigurable.swift       — Shared convenience APIs for list configurations
│   └── SectionModel.swift           — Section metadata (header/footer text)
├── DataSource/
│   ├── AutoReconfigure.swift        — Shared content-change detection algorithm
│   ├── ListDataSource.swift         — Single-cell-type data source with automatic registration
│   └── MixedListDataSource.swift    — Heterogeneous cell types via AnyItem type erasure
├── Builder/
│   ├── SnapshotBuilder.swift        — @resultBuilder for single-type snapshots
│   ├── ItemsBuilder.swift           — @resultBuilder for items within sections
│   ├── MixedSnapshotBuilder.swift   — @resultBuilder for mixed-type snapshots (also defines MixedItemsBuilder and MixedSection)
│   ├── DiffableDataSourceSnapshot+DSL.swift      — DSL extensions on Snapshot
│   └── DiffableDataSourceSnapshot+MixedDSL.swift — Mixed DSL extensions
├── Mixed/
│   └── AnyItem.swift                — Type-erased CellViewModel wrapper (measured overhead)
├── Configurations/
│   ├── SimpleList.swift             — Single-section flat list
│   ├── GroupedList.swift            — Multi-section with headers/footers
│   ├── OutlineList.swift            — Hierarchical expand/collapse
│   └── ListConfigurationBridge.swift — Shared configuration logic
├── SwiftUI/
│   ├── SimpleListView.swift         — SwiftUI wrapper for SimpleList
│   ├── GroupedListView.swift        — SwiftUI wrapper for GroupedList
│   ├── OutlineListView.swift        — SwiftUI wrapper for OutlineList
│   ├── SwiftUICellViewModel.swift   — Protocol adding SwiftUI body + accessories
│   ├── InlineCellViewModel.swift    — Type-erased inline SwiftUI content
│   └── ListAccessory.swift          — Pure-Swift enum for UICellAccessory
├── Extensions/
│   ├── CellViewModel+Identifiable.swift   — Default Hashable/Equatable from id
│   ├── LayoutHelpers.swift                — UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration shortcuts
│   └── RefreshControlConfiguration.swift  — Pull-to-refresh support
└── Lists.docc/                      — DocC documentation catalog
```

## Key Patterns

### CellViewModel Protocol

The single most important type in this module. A `CellViewModel` must:
1. Conform to `Hashable` and `Sendable`
2. Declare an associated `Cell` type (a `UICollectionViewCell` subclass)
3. Implement `func configure(_ cell: Cell)` to bind data to the cell

The default `Hashable`/`Equatable` implementations derive from `id`, provided by the `CellViewModel+Identifiable.swift` extension. Override only when content-based equality is needed.

### Result Builder DSL

The builders allow declarative snapshot construction:
```swift
dataSource.apply {
  SnapshotSection("favorites") {
    for item in favorites { item }
  }
  if showRecents {
    SnapshotSection("recents") {
      for item in recents { item }
    }
  }
}
```

`@SnapshotBuilder` and `@MixedSnapshotBuilder` are top-level; `@ItemsBuilder` and `@MixedItemsBuilder` are used inside sections.

### SwiftUI Integration

SwiftUI wrappers use `UIViewRepresentable`. The `SwiftUICellViewModel` protocol extends `CellViewModel` with a SwiftUI `body` and optional `accessories`. `InlineCellViewModel` is the type-erased version for inline closures.

### Mixed vs Single-Type

- `ListDataSource<Item>` — fastest path, no type erasure
- `MixedListDataSource` — wraps items in `AnyItem`, has measured overhead (~15-30%)
- Prefer single-type unless the list truly has heterogeneous cell types

## Critical Patterns

### Task Serialization (`applyTask` chain)

Any method that calls `await dataSource.apply(...)` **must** participate in the `applyTask` serialization chain. `@MainActor` does not prevent interleaving — `await` creates suspension points where other `@MainActor` code can run. Without serialization, overlapping applies corrupt snapshot state or header/footer dictionaries.

The pattern (used in `GroupedList.setSections`, `OutlineList.setItems`/`expand`/`collapse`, `MixedListDataSource.apply(content:)`):

```swift
applyTask?.cancel()
let previousTask = applyTask
let task = Task { [weak self] in
  _ = await previousTask?.value          // wait for previous to finish
  guard !Task.isCancelled, let self else { return }
  // ... build snapshot, merge headers ...
  await apply(snapshot, animatingDifferences: animatingDifferences)
  // ... trim headers ...
}
applyTask = task
await withTaskCancellationHandler {
  await task.value
} onCancel: {
  task.cancel()
}
```

If you add a new `async` method that applies snapshots, **you must use this pattern**.

### Header/Footer Merge-Then-Trim

When storing supplementary text (headers/footers) in dictionaries keyed by section ID, use the merge-then-trim strategy around animated applies:

1. **Merge** new values into existing dictionaries *before* applying the snapshot — ensures both old (animating out) and new sections resolve valid text during the transition
2. **Trim** to only new values *after* the apply completes — prevents stale entries from leaking

This pattern exists in `GroupedList.setSections` and `MixedListDataSource.apply(content:)`.

### ListConfigurable Protocol

The `ListConfigurable` protocol (in `Protocols/ListConfigurable.swift`) provides shared convenience APIs across `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList`. It derives ~15 default implementations from just four requirements: `collectionView`, `snapshot()`, `itemIdentifier(for:)`, and `indexPath(for:)`.

When adding a new convenience property or method that applies to all list configurations:
1. **Add it to `ListConfigurable`'s protocol extension** — all three configurations get it automatically
2. If the API needs configuration-specific behavior, add it directly to each configuration instead
3. `@objc` delegate methods (UICollectionViewDelegate, UIScrollViewDelegate) cannot be provided by protocol extensions — these remain duplicated by necessity

### Shared autoReconfigure Algorithm

The `computeItemsToReconfigure` function (in `DataSource/AutoReconfigure.swift`) implements the content-change detection algorithm shared by `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource`. Each data source passes its own equality closure:
- `ListDataSource`: type-level `ContentEquatable` check + `isContentEqualTypeErased`
- `MixedListDataSource`: `AnyItem.isContentEqual(to:)` (per-item type erasure)

## When Modifying This Module

- New `CellViewModel` features must work with both `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource`
- Result builders must support `if`/`else`, `for`, and `Optional` in all positions
- SwiftUI wrappers must call `updateUIView` correctly (avoid unnecessary reloads)
- All configurations are `@MainActor` — don't break actor isolation
- Any new `async` method that applies snapshots must use the `applyTask` serialization chain (see above)
- Run `make test-lists` to verify changes
- Run `make docs` if you changed any public API, doc comments (`///`), or files under `Lists.docc/` — commit the updated `docs/` output

content.thinking:
Now I have a complete picture. Let me plan all the changes I need to make:

### NEW Issues:

**1. Dead bridge methods** — Remove `scrollToItem`, `selectItem`, `deselectItem`, `isSelected`, `scrollToTop`, `scrollToBottom` from `ListConfigurationBridge.swift` (lines 135-213).

**2. Section snapshot flattening verification** — The code is intentional and documented. No code changes needed.

### Suggestions:

**3. Add explicit `internal` to `computeItemsToReconfigure`** — Add `internal` access modifier.

**4. Redundant `snapshot()` calls** — `numberOfItems` and `numberOfSections` each call `snapshot()` independently. I can change them to use `collectionView.numberOfSections` and a loop for `numberOfItems`, or just leave them. Actually, the cleaner fix is to use UICollectionView directly:


- `numberOfSections` → `collectionView.numberOfSections`
- `numberOfItems` → Sum of `collectionView.numberOfItems(inSection:)` across sections

The snapshot approach does give a consistent point-in-time view, but using the collection view's methods directly is equally valid and avoids the overhead of creating a snapshot copy.

Computing `numberOfItems` by summing across sections and `numberOfSections` directly from the collection view is simpler and cheaper than the snapshot approach.

I should also add a doc comment to `scrollToBottom` about requiring layout to be complete, and then look at extracting the shared section snapshot flattening logic that's duplicated elsewhere.

Examining the `apply` methods in both data sources, I'm seeing they follow the same pattern of capturing the old snapshot, validating the section exists, removing old items, and then applying the new visible items. Extracting a generic helper function... Finishing the snapshot application, then I'm deciding where to place this helper function—it makes sense to add it to `AutoReconfigure.swift` since both this and `computeItemsToReconfigure` are shared data source utilities. I'm also noting the UIScrollViewDelegate forwarding duplication as a known limitation that I'll document rather than over-engineer with a proxy pattern. approach I haven't considered: Since the scroll view delegate forwarding is identical code and only needs a `weak var scrollViewDelegate: UIScrollViewDelegate?` property, we can't add it to a protocol extension... But we COULD use a macro. Or we COULD use a code template.

Actually, the pragmatic answer: these 10 methods are 40 lines each class × 3 = 120 lines total. They're purely mechanical forwarding. The best we can do within Swift's type system is acknowledge the duplication with a clear comment and move on. The review itself says "the complexity may not be justified."

But the user said "fix all." So let me think once more... What if I create an `@objc protocol ScrollViewDelegateForwarding` that each class conforms to, and use method dispatch? No, that doesn't help with the implementation. What if each class uses a helper method to forward calls? That won't work either — I can't invoke arbitrary delegate methods by string name.

I'll document this as a known limitation with a clear MARK comment and accept that duplication is the right call given Swift's constraints. For the bridge initialization, the safety is already there through optional chaining and assertions, and the order concern is documented. The real issue is just the ceremony around setup, which is acceptable. I need to reconsider the approach since the bridge is created before the data source is available, so a factory method won't work. The real issue is that `itemIdentifier` and `indexPath` return nil silently when the data source isn't set yet, which could hide bugs. I should add assertion guards in those methods similar to what swipe actions already do, but I need to be careful because `resolveSeparator` explicitly documents why it doesn't assert—separators can fire during early layout before the data source is configured.

Looking at the actual usage, all three callers are correct and there's no way to statically enforce the ordering, so I'll leave the optional chaining as-is. Instead, I'll focus on three concrete improvements: removing six dead methods from ListConfigurationBridge, adding the `internal` access modifier to `computeItemsToReconfigure` and creating a shared `flattenSectionSnapshot` function in AutoReconfigure, and adding `[weak self]` guidance to the callback property documentation to prevent retain cycles.

Now I'm mapping out the specific file changes: ListConfigurationBridge needs those six dead methods removed, AutoReconfigure gets the new shared helper and access modifier, ListConfigurable needs to switch to using `collectionView` directly for item and section counts, ListDataSource and MixedListDataSource will use the new shared helper, and the list implementations need updated callback docs.

Before I start making changes, I should verify that calling `collectionView.numberOfItems(inSection:)` produces the same result as `snapshot().numberOfItems` — and it should, since the collection view's internal state is always consistent with the last applied snapshot.

For the implementation, I'm using a reduce function to sum up items across all sections rather than creating a snapshot copy, which is more efficient. The `numberOfSections` property just directly returns the collection view's section count.

Now I'm thinking through which callback properties need weak self warnings—basically all the stored closures like `onSelect`, `onDeselect`, `onDelete`, the swipe action providers, context menu provider, and the various data source callbacks could create retain cycles if the view controller holding the list captures itself directly in the closure.

Rather than cluttering every single callback with a warning across all three classes, I think the cleanest approach is to add a single note at the class level explaining the retain cycle risk, then maybe highlight it on the most prominent callback like `onSelect` so it's visible to users right away. callback) in each class, since it serves as the exemplar:

```swift
/// Called when the user taps an item.
///
/// - Important: This closure is stored strongly. If the closure captures the list's
///   owner (e.g. a view controller), use `[weak self]` to avoid a retain cycle.
public var onSelect: (@MainActor (Item) -> Void)?
```

Actually, that's adding noise to every callback. A better approach: add a single doc paragraph to the class doc comment that covers all callbacks at once:

```
/// ## Closure Callbacks
///
/// Callback properties (`onSelect`, `onDelete`, `trailingSwipeActionsProvider`, etc.) are
/// stored strongly. If the closure captures the list's owner, use `[weak self]` to avoid
/// a retain cycle.
```

This is the most practical solution. Let me add it to each of the 3 class doc comments.

Now for the UIScrollViewDelegate duplication—since I can't eliminate it due to @objc requirements, I'll add a clear comment explaining why the duplication exists, making it self-documenting.

Here's my sequence of edits: remove the dead bridge methods, update AutoReconfigure.swift with internal visibility and the flattened snapshot helper, update ListConfigurable.swift with the item/section count methods and scrolling docs, refactor ListDataSource.swift and MixedListDataSource.swift to use the new helper, add retain cycle guidance to the three list class comments, and finally document the @objc duplication pattern.

Starting now.

Good. I have a full picture of all the issues. Let me now make all the fixes systematically.

`★ Insight ─────────────────────────────────────`
**Issue triage summary**: Of the review findings, some are directly fixable in code (dead bridge methods, missing access modifiers, duplication, doc gaps), while one (UIScrollViewDelegate forwarding) is fundamentally constrained by Swift's `@objc`/protocol-extension limitation and can only be documented, not eliminated. The key architectural insight is that `@objc` dispatch goes through the Objective-C vtable, which protocol extensions cannot participate in — so these 10 methods must physically exist on each `NSObject` subclass.
`─────────────────────────────────────────────────`

**Fix 1**: Remove 6 dead bridge methods from `ListConfigurationBridge`.

`★ Insight ─────────────────────────────────────`
**"Pure function with closure" deduplication pattern**: Both `computeItemsToReconfigure` and the new `flattenSectionSnapshot` follow the same design: module-internal free functions that operate on value-type snapshots without capturing any state. This makes them trivially testable, thread-safe, and shareable between `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource` despite their different generic parameters.

   124→  ///
   125→  /// The section snapshot's ``DiffableDataSourceSectionSnapshot/visibleItems`` are flattened
   126→  /// into the target section; hierarchical parent–child structure is not preserved in the
   127→  /// underlying snapshot. Items whose wrapped type conforms to ``ContentEquatable`` are
   128→  /// automatically checked for content changes and marked for reconfiguration.
   129→  public func apply(

   131→    to section: SectionID,
   132→    animatingDifferences: Bool = true

   138→    var newSnapshot = oldSnapshot

   141→      assertionFailure("Cannot apply section snapshot to non-existent section \(section)")

   143→    }
   144→
   145→    let oldItems = newSnapshot.itemIdentifiers(inSection: section)
   146→    newSnapshot.deleteItems(oldItems)
   147→    let visibleItems = sectionSnapshot.visibleItems
   148→    if !visibleItems.isEmpty {
   149→      newSnapshot.appendItems(visibleItems, toSection: section)
   150→    }
   151→    await apply(newSnapshot, animatingDifferences: animatingDifferences)
   152→  }

# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.1.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added

- Added `ListConfigurable` protocol that provides shared convenience APIs (`backgroundView`, `allowsMultipleSelection`, `isEditing`, `numberOfItems`, `selectedItems`, `selectItem`, `deselectItem`, `deselectAll`, `scrollToTop`, `scrollToBottom`, `scrollToItem`, and more) via protocol extension — adding a new convenience method to this protocol automatically provides it to `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList`

### Changed

- Extracted shared `computeItemsToReconfigure` function from `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource`, deduplicating the autoReconfigure algorithm

### Fixed

- Fixed `MixedListDataSource.apply(_:to:animatingDifferences:)` bypassing `autoReconfigure`, so `ContentEquatable` items now correctly trigger reconfiguration when applied via section snapshots
- Fixed `OutlineList.setItems` not reconfiguring cells when `CellViewModel` conforms to `ContentEquatable` and content changes but identity stays the same ([#65](https://github.com/Iron-Ham/Lists/issues/65))

## [0.6.5] - 2026-02-20

### Fixed

- Removed dead convenience methods from `ListConfigurationBridge` (`scrollToItem`, `selectItem`, `deselectItem`, `isSelected`, `scrollToTop`, `scrollToBottom`) — now provided by `ListConfigurable` protocol extension

# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.1.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added

- Added `ListConfigurable` protocol that provides shared convenience APIs (`backgroundView`, `allowsMultipleSelection`, `isEditing`, `numberOfItems`, `selectedItems`, `selectItem`, `deselectItem`, `deselectAll`, `scrollToTop`, `scrollToBottom`, `scrollToItem`, and more) via protocol extension — adding a new convenience method to this protocol automatically provides it to `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList`

### Changed

- Extracted shared `computeItemsToReconfigure` function from `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource`, deduplicating the autoReconfigure algorithm

### Fixed

- Fixed `MixedListDataSource.apply(_:to:animatingDifferences:)` bypassing `autoReconfigure`, so `ContentEquatable` items now correctly trigger reconfiguration when applied via section snapshots
- Fixed `OutlineList.setItems` not reconfiguring cells when `CellViewModel` conforms to `ContentEquatable` and content changes but identity stays the same ([#65](https://github.com/Iron-Ham/Lists/issues/65))

## [0.6.5] - 2026-02-20

### Fixed

- Fixed Mac Catalyst refresh control guard to use process-level `UIDevice.current.userInterfaceIdiom` instead of `UIView.behavioralStyle`, which does not resolve correctly before the view is in a window hierarchy

## [0.6.4] - 2026-02-20

### Fixed

- Fixed crash when `onRefresh` is set on Mac Catalyst in Mac idiom — `UIRefreshControl` is now skipped when `behavioralStyle == .mac`, while apps using iPad idiom on Catalyst continue to get pull-to-refresh

## [0.6.3] - 2026-02-20

### Added

- Comprehensive animated apply test suite (21 tests) covering section insert/delete/move/replace, item reorder and cross-section moves, non-structural reload/reconfigure fast path, structural changes with deferred reload/reconfigure markers, background diff with large datasets (≥1,000 items), and rapid-fire serialization edge cases
- Deterministic cancellation tests verifying completion callback invocation and snapshot invariant safety when `applyTask` is cancelled mid-chain

### Fixed

- Completion handler `apply()` variant now supports cooperative cancellation and always invokes the completion callback (even when cancelled), preventing silent hangs for callers using `withCheckedContinuation`
- `performBatchUpdates` completion handler now checks the `finished` parameter — deferred reloads/reconfigures are skipped when UIKit interrupts the batch update

## [0.6.2] - 2026-02-19

### Fixed

- Fixed `NSInternalInconsistencyException` crash when applying snapshots with only inserts (no deletes) using animated differences — `currentSnapshot` is now updated inside the `performBatchUpdates` closure so UIKit sees correct pre/post item counts

### Added

- Animated apply regression tests covering pure inserts, pure deletes, empty↔populated transitions, and mixed cross-section operations

## [0.6.1] - 2026-02-18

### Changed

- `CollectionViewDiffableDataSource.performApply()` now offloads diff computation to a background thread for snapshots with ≥1,000 items, keeping the main thread free during large dataset updates

### Added

- Realistic UUID-based benchmarks comparing ListKit vs Apple using the `Item.ID` pattern with `Identifiable` model types
- Mixed operations benchmarks testing inserts + deletes + moves simultaneously across ListKit, Apple, and IGListKit
- Data source `apply()` benchmarks measuring the full end-to-end pipeline (diff + `performBatchUpdates`) for ListKit vs Apple

### Fixed

- `speedup()` benchmark helper now correctly handles durations >= 1 second (previously ignored the `seconds` component)

## [0.6.0] - 2026-02-16

### Added

- **Snapshot `Equatable` conformance**: `DiffableDataSourceSnapshot` now conforms to `Equatable`, comparing section identifiers and item arrays while ignoring transient reload/reconfigure markers.
- **Snapshot `init(sections:)` convenience initializer**: Build snapshots from `[(SectionID, [ItemID])]` pairs in a single call.
- **`sectionIdentifier(at:)` on `DiffableDataSourceSnapshot`**: Index-based section lookup, complementing the existing `index(ofSection:)`.
- **`replaceItems(in:with:)` on `DiffableDataSourceSnapshot`**: Bulk-replace all items in a section without deleting/re-appending the section.
- **`removeItems(where:)` on `DiffableDataSourceSnapshot`**: Remove items matching a predicate across all sections, following `removeAll(where:)` convention.
- **`children(of:)` on `DiffableDataSourceSectionSnapshot`**: Returns direct children of a given item, complementing the existing `parent(of:)`.
- **Programmatic selection**: `selectItem(_:at:animated:)`, `deselectItem(_:animated:)`, and `isSelected(_:)` on `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList`.
- **`shouldSelect` handler**: Closure on all three configurations (+ SwiftUI modifiers) that gates item selection via the `collectionView(_:shouldSelectItemAt:)` delegate.
- **`backgroundView` property**: Auto-visibility empty-state view on all three configurations (+ SwiftUI modifiers), shown when the list is empty and hidden when it has content.
- **`canMoveItemProvider`**: Per-item reorder predicate on `SimpleList` and `GroupedList` (+ SwiftUI modifiers).
- **`scrollToTop` / `scrollToBottom`**: Convenience scroll methods on all three configurations.
- **OutlineList tree queries**: `allItems`, `visibleItems`, `rootItems`, `parent(of:)`, and `level(of:)` for inspecting the outline hierarchy.
- **`SimpleList.items`**: Convenience accessor for the current items in the list.
- **Snapshot type aliases**: `SimpleList.Snapshot`, `GroupedList.Snapshot`, `OutlineList.Snapshot` for ergonomic snapshot type references.
- **`MixedSection` header/footer support**: Optional `header` and `footer` parameters on `MixedSection`, wired through `MixedListDataSource.apply(content:)` with `headerForSection(_:)`/`footerForSection(_:)` accessors and a `configureListHeaderFooterProvider()` convenience method for automatic supplementary view rendering.
- **`MixedListDataSource` reorder support**: `canMoveItemHandler` and `didMoveItemHandler` properties for drag-and-drop reordering parity with `ListDataSource`.
- **Section query methods on `GroupedList`**: `sectionIdentifier(for:)`, `index(for:)`, and `items(in:)` for section-level navigation.
- **`OutlineList` programmatic expand/collapse**: `expand(_:animated:)`, `collapse(_:animated:)`, and `isExpanded(_:)` methods for controlling outline hierarchy without rebuilding the tree.
- **`onMove` SwiftUI modifier**: `.onMove()` modifier on `SimpleListView` and `GroupedListView` for drag-and-drop reordering, completing the SwiftUI wrapper API.
- **Convenience query properties**: `numberOfItems`, `numberOfSections`, `selectedItems`, and `deselectAll(animated:)` on all three configurations (`SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, `OutlineList`).
- **`SectionModel.mapItems(_:)`**: Transforms items within a section while preserving metadata, matching `OutlineItem.mapItems(_:)` for API consistency.
- **`SectionModel` `Identifiable` conformance**: Enables direct use in SwiftUI `ForEach` and other `Identifiable`-requiring contexts.
- **`OutlineItem` `Identifiable` conformance**: Uses `item` as identity, enabling direct use in SwiftUI contexts.

## [0.5.0] - 2026-02-16

### Added

- **UIKit chat examples**: Two new UIKit counterparts to the existing SwiftUI chat example — `ListsChatExampleViewController` (`SimpleList` + `CellViewModel` + `UIHostingConfiguration`) and `ListKitChatExampleViewController` (raw `CollectionViewDiffableDataSource` with pure UIKit cells and manual cell reconfiguration).
- **Shared chat input bar**: Reusable `ChatInputBar` UIKit view with keyboard layout guide support.
- **`ListCellViewModel` protocol**: Convenience refinement of `CellViewModel` that defaults `Cell` to `UICollectionViewListCell`, eliminating the most common boilerplate `typealias`.
- **`UICollectionViewListCell.setListContent()` helpers**: Two convenience methods (parameter-based and closure-based) that replace the repetitive 4-line content configuration pattern with a single call.
- **SwiftUI-style view modifiers**: Chainable `.onSelect`, `.onDelete`, `.onRefresh`, `.editing`, `.contextMenu`, `.trailingSwipeActions`, `.leadingSwipeActions`, and more on `SimpleListView`, `GroupedListView`, and `OutlineListView`. Replaces the 19+ parameter initializer with an idiomatic init-then-modify pattern.
- **Pull-to-refresh on UIKit configurations**: `onRefresh` property on `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList` with proper async task lifecycle management, bringing parity with the SwiftUI wrappers.
- **`ContentEquatable` protocol**: Opt-in protocol for detecting content changes in identity-based view models. Automatically marks items for reconfiguration when content differs, solving the stale-UI footgun with `Identifiable` types.
- **`OutlineItemBuilder` result builder**: Declarative trailing-closure syntax for constructing `OutlineItem` hierarchies with full support for conditionals, loops, and arrays.
- **`SectionModel` `@ItemsBuilder` initializer**: Declarative builder-based section construction constrained to `CellViewModel` items.
- **`SnapshotSection` header/footer support**: `header` and `footer` optional parameters in the `SnapshotBuilder` DSL, wired through to `GroupedList.setSections`.
- **`Snapshot.contains(_:)` and `contains(section:)`**: Convenience queries using the reverse map for O(1) lookups when available.

### Changed

- **BREAKING: SwiftUI view initializers simplified**: `SimpleListView`, `GroupedListView`, and `OutlineListView` CellViewModel-based initializers now accept only layout/structural parameters. Behavioral properties (`onSelect`, `onDelete`, `onRefresh`, `editing`, etc.) must be set via the new chainable modifiers. Inline content initializers retain item-typed behavioral params (e.g., `onSelect`, `onDelete`) since they perform `Data → Item` wrapping.
- **Refresh control logic consolidated**: Extracted `RefreshControlManager` to replace triplicated refresh control code across `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList`.
- **Example app updated**: All UIKit examples use `ListCellViewModel` and `setListContent()`. `OutlineExampleViewController` uses builder DSL. `SwiftUIWrappersExampleView` demonstrates modifier-based configuration. `LiveExampleViewController` uses `ContentEquatable` for automatic reconfiguration.
- **Example app: expanded feature coverage**: DSL example uses `GroupedList` with `SnapshotSection` header/footer DSL and `Snapshot.contains(section:)`. GroupedList example demonstrates `@ItemsBuilder`, `ListAccessory.toggle`, `.progress`, and `.activityIndicator`. All three UIKit examples include pull-to-refresh. SwiftUI `GroupedDemoView` demonstrates `.editing` and `.allowsMultipleSelection` modifiers.

### Fixed

- **Chat example separators**: Added explicit `separatorHandler` to `ListsChatExampleViewController` to ensure separators are fully hidden, preventing `itemSeparatorHandler` from overriding `showsSeparators: false`.
- **Cell reuse accessory leak**: `setListContent()` now unconditionally assigns accessories, preventing stale accessories from persisting across cell reuse.
- **`ListAccessory.progress` crash**: Replaced `translatesAutoresizingMaskIntoConstraints = false` (which violates `UICellAccessory.customView` requirements) with `reservedLayoutWidth: .custom(60)`.

## [0.4.0] - 2026-02-15

### Added

- **`ListAccessory.toggle`**: Inline `UISwitch` accessory for settings screens with `isOn` binding and `onChange` callback.
- **`ListAccessory.badge`**: Pill-shaped count/status badge via `BadgeLabel` subclass with tint color propagation.
- **`ListAccessory.image`**: SF Symbol trailing icon accessory with debug assertions for invalid symbol names.
- **`ListAccessory.progress`**: Small inline progress bar (60pt width) with out-of-range value assertions.
- **`ListAccessory.activityIndicator`**: Spinning indicator accessory for loading states.

### Changed

- **`ListAccessory.uiAccessory`** is now `@MainActor`-isolated for UIKit thread safety.

## [0.3.0] - 2026-02-15

### Added

- **Scroll view delegate forwarding**: `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList` now forward `UIScrollViewDelegate` callbacks so consumers can receive scroll events without replacing the collection view's delegate.
- **`collectionViewHandler` and `scrollViewDelegate` parameters** added to `GroupedListView` and `OutlineListView` for API parity with `SimpleListView`.
- **`selfSizingInvalidation` parameter** on `SimpleList` and `SimpleListView` for controlling cell resize behavior during streaming content.
- **Chat example**: New `ChatExampleView` demonstrating streaming chat with manual layout invalidation, scroll-to-bottom tracking, and bubble-scoped context menus.

## [0.2.0] - 2026-02-15

### Added

- **`onDelete` callback**: Automatic trailing swipe action generation for item deletion across all list configurations.
- **`onMove` with drag-and-drop reorder**: Full drag-and-drop reorder infrastructure on `SimpleList` and `GroupedList` with `canMoveItemHandler` and `didMoveItemHandler` callbacks.
- **`onDeselect` callback**: Multi-selection deselection support forwarded through all SwiftUI wrappers.
- **`showsSeparators` parameter**: Native UIKit separator visibility toggle on all list configurations and `LayoutHelpers` factory methods.
- **`ListAccessory.label`**: Text label accessory case.
- **`ListAccessory.detail`**: Detail accessory with optional action handler.
- **`ListAccessory.multiselect`**: Multi-selection checkmark accessory.
- **`ListAccessory.popUpMenu`**: Pop-up menu accessory.
- **UICollectionLayoutListConfiguration support**: `separatorColor`, `backgroundColor`, `headerTopPadding` across all list types with `separatorHandler` for per-item separator customization.
- **Header/footer configuration**: `headerMode`/`footerMode` and `headerContentProvider`/`footerContentProvider` on `GroupedList`.
- **Selection APIs**: `allowsMultipleSelection`, `allowsSelectionDuringEditing`, `allowsMultipleSelectionDuringEditing`, and `isEditing` computed property on all list types.
- **Navigation APIs**: `itemIdentifier(for:)`, `indexPath(for:)`, and `scrollToItem(_:)` on all list configurations.
- **`GroupedList.setSections` with `SnapshotBuilder` DSL** for declarative section updates.
- **`ListLayout` factory methods** for all compositional layout appearance styles.
- **`dismantleUIView`** added to all SwiftUI wrappers for deterministic cleanup.
- **`buildLimitedAvailability`** added to all four result builders.
- **`withTaskCancellationHandler`** support to propagate cancellation from structured parent tasks during SwiftUI coordinator teardown.

### Changed

- **`SectionModel` `Item` constraint** relaxed to `Hashable & Sendable`, fixing inline-content convenience initializers for plain data types.
- **`SwipeActionBridge` renamed to `ListConfigurationBridge`**: Centralizes shared delegate logic, item navigation, and scroll-to-item into a single bridge to eliminate duplication across list types.
- **Rapid-render coalescing**: New updates now cancel previous pending applies for faster UI convergence.
- **UIKit layout closures** wrapped in `MainActor.assumeIsolated` for Swift 6 strict concurrency readiness.
- **`OutlineList.setItems`** now uses native section snapshot apply instead of flat snapshot rebuild, enabling UIKit's optimized subtree diffing and native expand/collapse animations.

### Fixed

- **Section snapshot parent map corruption**: Fixed `snapshot(of:includingParent:)` where dangling parent references were copied for extracted subtrees.
- **Multi-selection**: Guard `deselectItem` behind `!allowsMultipleSelection` so multi-selection workflows function correctly.
- **Snapshot/UI mismatch**: Serialized `applySnapshotUsingReloadData` through the apply task chain to prevent interleaving with animated applies.
- **Stale snapshot on deallocation**: Always update `currentSnapshot` before the `guard` when `collectionView` is deallocated.
- **GroupedList header/footer atomicity**: Use merge-then-trim pattern during animated transitions.
- **Snapshot data loss in move operation**: Validate destination section bounds before deleting item in `moveItemAt`.
- **`deinit` task cancellation** added to `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, and `OutlineList` to cancel lingering tasks on deallocation.
- **Refresh control cleanup**: Use `defer` in `handleRefresh` to ensure `refreshTask` cleanup and spinner dismissal run on all exit paths.

### Performance

- **LIS-based minimal move detection**: Replaced naive diff move detection with longest-increasing-subsequence algorithm using O(n log n) patience sorting, eliminating unnecessary batch update animations.

## [0.1.0] - 2026-02-13

### Added

- **SwiftUI wrappers**: `SimpleListView`, `GroupedListView`, and `OutlineListView` — `UIViewRepresentable` wrappers driven by `@State`.
- **Inline content API**: `@ViewBuilder` convenience initializers on all three SwiftUI wrappers. Define cell content inline without creating a dedicated `CellViewModel` type.
- **`SwiftUICellViewModel` protocol**: Protocol for reusable SwiftUI-based cell view models with `body` and `accessories`.
- **`InlineCellViewModel`**: Type-erased `CellViewModel` backing the inline content API.
- **`ListAccessory`**: Pure-Swift enum wrapping `UICellAccessory` with a `.custom` escape hatch.
- **Swipe actions**: Leading and trailing swipe action support on all three list configurations and their SwiftUI wrappers.
- **Context menus**: Context menu support on all three list configurations and their SwiftUI wrappers.
- **Pull-to-refresh**: `onRefresh` async closure on all three SwiftUI wrappers with automatic `UIRefreshControl` lifecycle management.
- **`OutlineItem.mapItems`**: Recursive tree transformation for mapping data types across outline hierarchies.
- **`OutlineItem` `Equatable` conformance**: Enables diffing in SwiftUI `updateUIView`.

### Changed

- **`OutlineItem` generic constraint** relaxed from `CellViewModel` to `Hashable & Sendable`, enabling use with plain data types.
- **`SwiftUICellViewModel.accessories`** return type changed from `[UICellAccessory]` to `[ListAccessory]`.
- **Task serialization** added to `SimpleList.setItems`, `GroupedList.setSections`, and `OutlineList.setItems` to prevent concurrent snapshot applies.
- **Supplementary view bounds checking** added to `GroupedList` header/footer registration.

## [0.0.1] - 2025-12-20

Initial development release.

### Added

- **ListKit**: O(n) Heckel diff engine, `DiffableDataSourceSnapshot`, `DiffableDataSourceSectionSnapshot`, `CollectionViewDiffableDataSource`.
- **Lists**: `CellViewModel` protocol, `ListDataSource`, `MixedListDataSource`, `AnyItem`, result-builder DSL (`SnapshotBuilder`, `ItemsBuilder`, `MixedSnapshotBuilder`), `SimpleList`, `GroupedList`, `OutlineList` configurations, layout helpers.
- Swift 6 strict concurrency support.
- MIT license.

lines: - Extracted shared `computeItemsToReconfigure` function from `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource`, deduplicating the autoReconfigure algorithm
+- Extracted shared `flattenSectionSnapshot` function from `ListDataSource` and `MixedListDataSource`, deduplicating the section snapshot flattening logic

+- Removed dead convenience methods from `ListConfigurationBridge` (`scrollToItem`, `selectItem`, `deselectItem`, `isSelected`, `scrollToTop`, `scrollToBottom`) — now provided by `ListConfigurable` protocol extension

1→// ABOUTME: Shared data source algorithms for content-change detection and section snapshot flattening.
     2→// ABOUTME: Used by ListDataSource and MixedListDataSource.
     3→import ListKit
     4→
     5→/// Computes items that need reconfiguration by comparing old and new snapshots.
     6→///
     7→/// For items that match by identity (`Hashable`/`Equatable`) in both snapshots, calls
     8→/// `isContentEqual` to determine whether visible content has changed. Returns items
     9→/// from the new snapshot whose content differs from their counterparts in the old snapshot.
    10→///
    11→/// - Parameters:
    12→///   - old: The previous snapshot before the update.
    13→///   - new: The new snapshot being applied.
    14→///   - isContentEqual: Closure that returns `true` when two identity-matching items have equal content.
    15→/// - Returns: Items from `new` whose content differs from their counterpart in `old`.
    16→func computeItemsToReconfigure<SectionID: Hashable & Sendable, Item: Hashable & Sendable>(
    17→  old: DiffableDataSourceSnapshot<SectionID, Item>,
    18→  new: DiffableDataSourceSnapshot<SectionID, Item>,
    19→  isContentEqual: (Item, Item) -> Bool
    20→) -> [Item] {
    21→  let oldItems = old.itemIdentifiers
    22→  guard !oldItems.isEmpty else { return [] }
    23→
    24→  var oldLookup = [Item: Item]()
    25→  oldLookup.reserveCapacity(oldItems.count)
    26→  for item in oldItems {
    27→    oldLookup[item] = item
    28→  }
    29→
    30→  var toReconfigure = [Item]()
    31→  for newItem in new.itemIdentifiers {
    32→    guard let oldItem = oldLookup[newItem] else { continue }
    33→    if !isContentEqual(newItem, oldItem) {
    34→      toReconfigure.append(newItem)
    35→    }
    36→  }
    37→  return toReconfigure
    38→}
    39→
    40→/// Flattens a section snapshot's visible items into a full snapshot, replacing the target section's items.
    41→///
    42→/// Returns a new snapshot with the section's items replaced by the section snapshot's
    43→/// ``DiffableDataSourceSectionSnapshot/visibleItems``. Hierarchical parent–child structure
    44→/// is not preserved in the returned snapshot.
    45→///
    46→/// - Parameters:
    47→///   - sectionSnapshot: The hierarchical section snapshot to flatten.
    48→///   - section: The section whose items should be replaced.
    49→///   - snapshot: The current full snapshot.
    50→/// - Returns: A new snapshot with flattened items, or `nil` if the section does not exist.
    51→func flattenSectionSnapshot<SectionID: Hashable & Sendable, Item: Hashable & Sendable>(
    52→  _ sectionSnapshot: DiffableDataSourceSectionSnapshot<Item>,
    53→  intoSection section: SectionID,
    54→  of snapshot: DiffableDataSourceSnapshot<SectionID, Item>
    55→) -> DiffableDataSourceSnapshot<SectionID, Item>? {
    56→  var newSnapshot = snapshot
    57→  guard newSnapshot.sectionIdentifiers.contains(section) else {
    58→    assertionFailure("Cannot apply section snapshot to non-existent section \(section)")
    59→    return nil
    60→  }
    61→  let oldItems = newSnapshot.itemIdentifiers(inSection: section)
    62→  newSnapshot.deleteItems(oldItems)
    63→  let visibleItems = sectionSnapshot.visibleItems
    64→  if !visibleItems.isEmpty {
    65→    newSnapshot.appendItems(visibleItems, toSection: section)
    66→  }
    67→  return newSnapshot
    68→}
    69→
